question: Don't wait up, AL.
answer: Ten police cruisers frozen solid on the Gotham Expressway . . .

question: ... A giant drilling truck burrowing under the city ...
answer: Mr. Freeze.

question: The batcomputer tracks him heading for the Gotham Museum.
answer: The new antiquities exhibit. The Second Sun of the Sudan.

question: Of course. He's going to steal the giant white diamond.
answer: No, Robin. He's going to jail.

question: What killed the dinosaurs? The ice age. Hit me boys. Thanks for playing.
answer: Stop the insanity.

question: Nice of you to drop in.
answer: You were a great scientist once. Don't squander your genius on evil.

question: I hate being lectured. Watch the numbers, Batman. For they are the harbingers of your doom. Can you feel it coming? The icy cold of space. At 30,000 feet your heart will freeze and beat no more. After you have frozen, your icy tomb will plummet back to Gotham.
answer: Freeze, you're mad. This capsule will slaughter thousands.

question: I was just hanging around.
answer: I thought you were going to stay in the museum and round up the thugs.

question: How about, nice to see you? Glad you're here to save my life.
answer: When we get home, we're having a little communication workshop.

question: Is it cold in here or is it just me?
answer: Got to make sure this rocket doesn't turn Gotham into a crater.

question: Now what? We call a taxi?
answer: Watch the first step.

question: Surf's up. Cool. Can we do that again?
answer: Wind.

question: I still have high hopes for the animal plant cross-breedings If I can only find the correct dose of Venom, these plants will be able to fight back like animals. I will have given flora a chance against the thoughtless ravages of man. Personal note
answer: Dr. Isley, loveliest flower in our garden. How fare our little wards? What do we have here? A lovely new supply of Venom. I'll just take this to my laboratory for further study.

question: What exactly are you working on in there? What are those screams?
answer: How I'd love to share my secrets with you. But I ask you, sweet sapling, can you be trusted? You refuse my invitations to dine. You hide your honeyed buds behind these sallow robes. Ah, but there's romance in the air tonight. Perhaps a moonlit stroll in the jungle. And then, later, in the dark, we can share everything.

question: You have to tell me what you're doing with my Venom.
answer: You must show me your secrets, blossom, before I show you mine. Ladies and gentlemen of the un-United Nations. And our mystery bidder. I give you the future of military conquest. May I present Antonio Diego, serial murderer serving life in prison and sole surviving volunteer. And what a charmer he is. The super solder serum, code named Venom, patent pending of course. Notice the hassle free zipper. Time to scream. Behold, the ideal killing machine. I call this little number...Bane. Bane of humanity. Imagine it, your own personal army made up of thousands of these super soldiers. Bidding begins at a mere 10 million. Welcome to my parlor. ...Our original sponsor had no stomach for military applications. he cut the funding for our work -

question: Our work?
answer: Without your research, I could never have come this far. Join me. The two of us, entwined, side by side...

question: Join you? I've spent my life trying to protect plants from extinction and now you corrupt my research into some maniacal scheme for world domination. When I get through you won't be able to get a job teaching high school chemistry, do you hear me, you psycho?
answer: Well, I can respect your opinion. Sadly, I'm not good at rejection. I'm afraid you'll have to die. Fellow maniacs, bidding begins!

question: Gotham University Labs. Security video. Two years ago. Dr. Victor Fries Two time Olympic Decathelete. Nobel Prize winner in molecular biology. After his wife contracted a rare disease, McGregor's Syndrome, he hoped to freeze her in cryogenic sleep until he could discover a cure. Here's where everything goes north. That liquid is fifty below.
answer: That's gotta hurt.

question: Somehow he survived. But the cryoslution mutated his body.
answer: What happened to his wife?

question: Presumed dead. No one knows. He needs extreme cold to survive. His cryo-suit uses diamond enhanced lasers to keep him at zero degrees.
answer: Let me get this straight. A brilliant citizen, disfigured by a horrible accident, re-emerges as a psychotic super-villain bent on theft, revenge and destruction. You see a pattern here?

question: < Maybe it's something in the water. Well, if it's ice the iceman wants...Alfred! I need the Wayne Diamonds.
answer: We gonna trap ourselves a snowman?

question: Absolutely. Just as soon as you take ten hours training in the simulator.
answer: Whoa, I made a mistake. I'm sorry. Don't go all protective on me. It won't happen again.

question: Dick, you were reckless. You could have been killed.
answer: I'm fine. See. Me. here. Alive. How are we gonna work together if you're never going to trust me?

question: How, indeed?
answer: When did I become the bad guy? He's over-eager, impulsive. I can't trust him not to get hurt.

question: Perhaps the truth is you don't really trust anyone.
answer: Don't tell me you're on his side. Again.

question: Despite all your talents, you are still a novice in the ways of family. Dick follows the same ends as you but gets there by his own course. You must learn to trust him. For that is the nature of family.
answer: I trust you, Alfred.

question: I'm on break from-
answer: Oxbridge Academy?

question: Their new computer sciences division. How did you know?
answer: I recognized the accent.

question: I didn't know sneaking around was on the curriculum at Oxbridge.
answer: I'm sorry, Uncle, I came to tuck you in. And...

question: You came to tuck me in. That's quite a switch. I am looking for my brother, Wilfred. He is first butler to the Maharajah of Mirajanpore. But Mirajanpore is a floating court, it travels across India, so Wilfred can be rather difficult to find.
answer: I guess they don't have fax machines on elephants.

question: I have been trying to reach Wilfred with no success. As one grows older, one yearns for family.
answer: It's good to see you again, Uncle. I've missed you.

question: Get married? me? No...
answer: No!?

question: Umm. What I mean is...no plans at the moment...
answer: But soon...

question: Ah...Sooner or later...all relationships evolve and...
answer: And?

question: Can I get some help over here?
answer: Bruce and I are lucky enough to be recklessly in love. And that is most certainly enough for us. For now.

question: They're overly protective. You're Not going to hurt me are you, Ms...
answer: Dr. Pamela Isley.

question: What can I do for you, Doctor? A research grant? A hospital wing?
answer: Actually, I already work for you. Or did. Your arboreal preservation project in South America.

question: We cut our support. A conflict of ideologies. Dr. Woodrue was a lunatic.
answer: I see you knew him.

question: That lab was consumed by fire last week. how did you manage to escape?
answer: I have here a proposal showing how Wayne Enterprises can immediately cease all actions that toxify our environment. Forget the stars. Look here, at the Earth, our mother, our womb. She deserves our loyalty and protection. And yet you spoil her lands, poison her oceans, blacken her skies. You're killing her.

question: Your intentions are noble, but no diesel fuel for heat. No coolants to preserve food. Millions would die of cold and hunger alone.
answer: Acceptable losses in a battle to save the planet.

question: People come first, Dr. Isley.
answer: Mammals. So smug in your towers of stone and glass. A day of reckoning is coming. The same plants and flowers that saw you crawl blind from the primordial soup will reclaim this planet. Earth will be a garden again. Somehow, some way, I will bring your man-made civilization to its knees and there will be no one to protect you.

question: Did I use the wrong door again? I should have been a decorator. Let me guess, Plant Girl? Vine Lady? Ms. Moss?
answer: Listen, Captain Cold, the suit, maybe, even though silver went out in the 70's. But those boots are unforgivable. What is it with men?

question: I'd love to stand here all day and exchange fashion tips but I'm kind of pressed for time. So hand over the diamond, Garden Gal, or I turn you into mulch. Pheromone dust. Designed to heat a man's blood. Doesn't work on the cold hearted. Now, if you please...
answer: Well, if you insist.

question: I'm putting you on ice.
answer: I could have made the jump.

question: You could have splattered your brains on the side of the building.
answer: This is no partnership. You're never going to trust me.

question: Trust you? You can't even keep your head on the job. All you could think about was Poison Ivy.
answer: You just can't stand that she might have wanted me instead of you; that's your idea of friendship, isn't it, Bruce? You have to have everything. Your house. Your rules. Your way or the highway. It's Batman and Robin not Robin and Batman. I'm sick of it.

question: Yes it's my rules. My rules that keep us alive. And if you want to stay in this house and on this team then you'll abide by them.
answer: I have tried every address I know for you. I am praying this reaches you. We have very little time. Congratulations on your apprehension of Mr. Freeze. Batman monopolized the evening news.

question: Thanks.
answer: Is there something wrong, sir?

question: Alfred, am I pigheaded? Is it always my way or the highway?
answer: Why, yes, actually. Death and chance stole your parents. But rather than become a victim, you have done everything in your power to control the fates. For what is Batman if not an effort to master the chaos that sweeps our world, an attempt to control death itself.

question: But I can't can I?
answer: No, my boy. I'm afraid none of us can.

question: You're not even listening to me.
answer: What? I'm sorry. You were saying...

question: We've been going out over a year now and...Okay, here goes. Bruce, I want to spend my life with you.
answer: Julie, I'm not the marrying kind. There are things about me you wouldn't understand.

question: I know you're a dedicated bachelor. That you've had a your wild nights.
answer: Wild doesn't exactly cover it.

question: But there's nothing you've done under the cover of darkness I couldn't learn to understand.
answer: I wouldn't bet on that.

question: I'm betting on you. You'll make someone a good husband one day. But I can't wait around forever. Don't answer now. Just think it over. Here's some food for thought. Who's Ivy?
answer: What?

question: You just called me Ivy. Who's Ivy?
answer: I wish I knew.

question: Enhance detail, 14 to 19. Who are you? Got ya!
answer: What's the entry fee? Folks call me Three-Jump. How about a side bet?

question: So, this is where you hang out.
answer: I could have made it, you know. I didn't need your help.

question: Whatever you say, lady. It's all in a day's work for me.
answer: This is to replace the bike I lost. I'll get you the rest.

question: Keep it.
answer: Of course, Dick Grayson, ward of the fabulously wealthy Bruce Wayne. Why would you need a few hundred dollars?

question: Hey, what's your problem?
answer: I guess, the truth is I'm just not comfortable with the idle rich. Even when they try to act like heroes.

question: Well you better get comfortable real fast, sister. Cause we've only got one bike and it's a long walk home.
answer: I started racing after my parents died. There was something about the speed, the danger, that took me out of myself, that made the hurt go away. You wouldn't understand.

question: You'd be surprised.
answer: Street racing isn't exactly an acceptable major at Oxbridge. They kicked me out. it doesn't matter. I've won enough money to do what I've always dreamed.

question: Just don't tell me you're hoping to run away and join the circus.
answer: Alfred has supported me my whole life. Now I'm going to pay him back. I'm going to liberate him from his dismal life of servitude.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: Servants, Masters, it's ridiculous. Alfred is the sweetest, most noble man alive and he's subjugated all his life and dreams to someone else.

question: Alfred and Bruce are like family.
answer: Paying someone to prepare your meals and do your laundry and clean your dishes, you call that family?

question: Alfred's happy here.
answer: Happy. You honestly don't know, do you? You can't even see what's in front of your own eyes. Look at his skin. At how he's hiding the pain all the time. Can't you see it? Alfred's sick.

question: Alfred's not sick. He's dying. And I can't deal with it.
answer: But he's never said a word-

question: You know Alfred. He'd never say Anything. But I can tell. Until you came along, Alfred was the only family I ever had. Without him, I don't know how I would have survived. He saved my life, Dick. And I've never told him.
answer: Talk to him, Bruce. There's nothing worse than losing someone without telling them how you feel.

question: I really am to die for.
answer: Impressive

question: Well, I, my most unabominable snowman, have been impressed by you. In fact I propose a pairing. So I'm here to set you free.
answer: An enticing offer. But what does the lady want in return?

question: Let's cool it for now. There's someone I want you to meet.
answer: Ah, a laundry service that delivers.

question: I love that belt. What are you, about a fifty Big and Tall?
answer: I always go a size smaller. Makes me look slimmer. They've confiscated my generator diamonds. I'm running on empty.

question: Not good.
answer: No gun. How disarming.

question: I wonder if I can get a cell with a view of the gardens?
answer: Dear daisy, don't despair. Always winterize your pipes.

question: I hate heights.
answer: You'll hate prison more.

question: Are you well, old friend?
answer: I am as well as can be expected.

question: Alfred, I know you're sick -- I can get you the best doctors.
answer: I've seen the best doctors--! A gentleman does not discuss his health. It's not civilized. I hope I've taught you at least that much, young man.

question: Have you ever regretted your life working here, Alfred?
answer: Attending to heroes? No sir. My Only regret is that I was never able to be out there with you.

question: Not all heroes wear masks. Alfred, if I've never told you...I just want to say...
answer: Yes?

question: My reserves are exhausted. I must have the gems that power my suit.
answer: You are looking unseasonably hot. Let's go inside and grab your rocks.

question: In my weakened state I am no match for the bat and the bird.
answer: You leave Batman and Robin to me. Trust me. Vegetable magnetism.

question: Fine. While I retrieve my diamonds, you and meatloaf will bring my wife to your lair. She's frozen in -
answer: Hold it. You never said anything about a wife, frozen or otherwise-

question: You will rescue my wife
answer: OK, OK. Ms. Ivy to the rescue. Now where do I find your brittle bride?

question: She's definitely part of this. It's weird, for a while Ivy was all I could think about. But then...
answer: I know. The feeling just vanished.

question: I can't believe we were fighting over a bad guy.
answer: Bad, yes. Guy, no. This is one majorly beautiful evil person.

question: I'm totally over her. Positively.
answer: Me too. Great stems, though.

question: Umm-hmmmm.
answer: Definitely.

question: How did you...?
answer: Open Sesame...Chicken. She's still alive. He's adapted his freezing technology to reverse McGregor's Syndrome. He's even found a cure for the early stages of the disease.

question: Can he save her?
answer: No. Her case is too advanced. But maybe, someday, with more research- No beauty...

question: You bring out the animal in me.
answer: I should have brought my leash.

question: Enough sweet talk.
answer: You're going to jail.

question: Remember the victim at the airport. Toxins introduced through the mouth.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: Why is she so desperate to kiss us? I'm betting her lips are poison.
answer: A poison kiss? You have some real issues with women, you know that? You just couldn't stand that she was about to kiss me. Couldn't stand that something might be mine and not yours. Could you?!

question: Damn.
answer: Ivy's right. I don't need you. I'm going solo. I want my own signal in the sky.

question: So sorry, Ms. Fridigaire. I'm just not good with competition. Make yourself right at home.
answer: Where is my wife?

question: There was nothing I could do. Batman deactivated her. She's dead.
answer: You lie!

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Their bones will turn to ice. Their blood will freeze in my hands.

question: Kill them. Of course. But why stop there? Why should only Batman and Robin die while the society that created them goes unpunished?
answer: Yes. I shall replay the world for sentencing me to a life without the warmth of human comfort. I will blanket the city in endless winter. First Gotham and then the world.

question: Just what I had in mind. Everything dead on Earth except us. A chance for mother nature to start again. Plants and flowers are the oldest species on the planet yet they are defenseless against man. Sorry hon, this is for science. Behold the dawn of a new age. I have created a race of plants with the strength of the deadliest animals. Once you have frozen mankind, my mutants will overrun the globe. The Earth will become a brave new world of only plants. And we shall rule them. For we will be the only two people left in the world.
answer: Adam and Evil. You will distract the bat and bird while I prepare to freeze Gotham.

question: Can't we just ice them along with the rest of the citizenry?
answer: That is far too merciful. Batman will watch his beloved Gotham perish, then I will kill him.

question: As a team, the duncely duo protect each other. But the Robin is young. Impetuous. If I could get him alone-
answer: One kiss and you could lift the mask from his lifeless face. Their secret identities would be revealed. But how best to bait a brid?

question: The way to a boy's heart is through his ego. What strapping young hero could resist his very own...signal?
answer: Inspired, Ms. Ivy.

question: McGregor's Syndrome. That's what Freeze's wife had.
answer: Yes. But Alfred's condition is less severe. Freeze's research says he cured a case like Alfred's. It just doesn't say how.

question: I checked the medical database. No one else is even close.
answer: I'm late for the dedication. Then I go after Freeze and Ivy. Alone.

question: Like hell you do.
answer: Dick, don't push me right now.

question: Or what? No one can capture Ivy but the big bad Bat. Crap! You just want her for yourself. Don't you? Answer me, damn it!
answer: Yes! Yes, I want her so badly I can taste it. That's the whole point. Look at us. Orphans. Isolated. Obsessed to the exclusion of life, love, family. We're perfect targets. She's done something to us, got us fighting over her somehow.

question: Hail the all-knowing Bruce Wayne. Here's what I know, she loves me, Not you and it's driving you crazy. It's why you stopped us from kissing. Because if you can't have her, nobody can.
answer: She's clouded your mind. You're not thinking straight.

question: I'm sorry. I was too late.
answer: Too late for what, dear child?

question: I came to give you your freedom, a chance to live the life you choose. The same gift you gave me.
answer: I have been part of the greatest adventure ever know. I have found purpose here, and the family I could never have. You must do something for me. Find my brother Wilfred. Give him This. I have duties he must fulfill in my stead. Only family can be trusted.

question: What is it?
answer: It is the hearts of two good men whom I have had the honor of calling son. Take it, child. But I implore you, never open it. You look so like your mother.

question: I've heard of commitment anxiety, but this is insane. You're not really propositioning another woman right in front of me. Are you?
answer: Well, define 'propositioning'.

question: Make a choice, Bruce. Her or me.
answer: Well...um...her.

question: Alfred, old friend, I could use your help right now.
answer: Right here, sir. I anticipated a moment might arrive where I became...incapacitated. As such, I programmed my brain algorithms into the batcomputer and created a virtual simulation.

question: It's good to see you.
answer: What seems to be the problem?

question: Women.
answer: That, sir, does not compute.

question: First Ivy had an intoxicating effect on both Dick and me. Tonight my feelings spread to someone else.
answer: Specify, please.

question: Pamela Isley. I was so attracted to her I couldn't reason clearly. I still can't. She used to work for Wayne Enterprises. Find a file.
answer: Coming on line now, sir.

question: What was her area of research?
answer: Advanced botany. DNA splicing. Recombinant animal plant patterns. Pheromone extractions.

question: Pheromones?
answer: Glandular secretions from animals. Scents that create powerful emotions. Fear. Rage...

question: Passion. Of course. Find the photo of Ivy after the flower ball. Deconstruct and resolve. Amazing what a good wig and contact lenses can do. And I thought Clark Kent got away with murder just wearing those glasses. What is it?
answer: It appears, sir, that someone has stolen the batsignal.

question: That's no batlight, it's a birdcall.
answer: Her name is Pamela Isley. I saw her talking to Gordon. She must have stolen his keys, altered the signal-

question: And she did it all for me. For love.
answer: She's infected us with some kind of pheromone extract-

question: Is that it, Bruce? I'm under some magic spell?
answer: She wants to kill you.

question: You'd say anything to keep me away from her. To keep her for yourself.
answer: You once said to me that being part of a team means trusting your partner. That sometimes counting on someone else is the only way to win. DO you remember? You weren't just talking about being partners. You were talking about being a family. Well, part of our family is dying. I'm not going to lose everyone I've ever loved. So I'm asking you now, friend, partner, brother - will you trust me?

question: I'm glad you came. I can't breathe without you.
answer: I want us to be together. But I need to know you're serious about turning over a new leaf. I need a sign.

question: How about dangerous curves?
answer: Of trust. Tell me your plan.

question: Kiss me and I'll tell you.
answer: Tell me and I'll kiss you.

question: Freeze has turned the new telescope into a freezing gun. He's about to turn Gotham into an ice cube.
answer: I've got to stop him.

question: One kiss, my love. For luck. Bad luck, I'm afraid. It's time to die, little bird.
answer: What do you mean?

question: You should have heeded your pointy- eared pal. These lips can be murder.
answer: Then you never loved me?

question: Love you? I loathe your bipedal arrogance, your animal superiority. My only joy is knowing that even now my poison kiss is sucking the life from your ape-like face. You're too late. Say bye-bye birdie.
answer: Sorry to disappoint you. But rubber lips are immune to your charms.

question: Crimefighter's rule number two.
answer: I'm afraid to ask.

question: Be ready for anything.
answer: Pow! What! Kazow!

question: What exactly are you doing?
answer: I don't know. It just feels right.
